results.title: Energy and matter
results.creator_credit: Robert Verrall, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A look at energy and what it is, designed to encourage understanding and experimentation among even the youngest of budding physicists. This film pictures energy in familiar forms - light, heat, motion, etc. - and shows its origin in the sun. The illustration is cartoon-style, with color and movement appealing to youthful imaginations.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 4-6.
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Mark Sanders, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode four, “Being in a union”, is about the various functions performed by trade unions. In “Using public transport” a man used to driving everywhere finds that public transport can turn out to be much more convenient: but only once you can understand timetables and how to access information. And in “Using a phone” information is given on some of the barriers that inhibit people from using a phone effectively.

results.title: Energy
results.brief_description: Shows the mining of coal, its conversion into electrical energy, and the problems enocuntered in this conversion such as the disposal of waste products. Also looks at atomic power stations and their inherent problems. The concept of tidal power as an alternative source is mentioned. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: English at work. - Eps. 34-36.
results.creator_credit: Michael Karris, Richard Jasek, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: The final three episodes of the “English at work” series. In “Helping with problems” we are shown the various ways people can assist others by being good listeners and being prepared to stand up for the rights of others. In “Saving energy” we are shown ways to be more energy efficient at both work and home. “Preventing sexual harassment”. The prevention of sexual harassment and intimidation is shown to be the responsibility of management, workers, and unions: in fact every woman and man needs to object to the practice of harassment in their workplace whenever it occurs.

results.title: End of a summers day
results.creator_credit: Robert Fortier, Don Rennick, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A comment without words on the ancient theme of love and war: the man called to arms for his country; his sweetheart left behind to mourn; sorrow and separation visited upon the innocent. This is how it has always been, but implicit in the film are the protests of a new generation: Must it always be so? Is not love better than war? Cast includes: Michel Gauthier, Dennis Nadeau, Caroline Price, Paul Sullivan. (Award: New York)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Fortier, Don Rennick, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 28-30.
results.creator_credit: Michael Karris, Robert Bull, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Buying a car, new or used, can often be a stressful time because of the money involved. The first episode of this video details the importance of organising appropriate finance, being sure of exactly what kind of vehicle you need, and knowing what questions to ask dealers (be they a business or an individual) before buying your car. In “Deciding where to live” information is given on the various types of housing that exist in Australia - private, public, rental, home ownership and emergency housing. Episode 30, “Getting your skills recognised” explains the various services available for migrants to Australia to receive assistance in getting overseas qualifications recognised, and also explains how to arrange upgrading skills for the Australian workplace.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 25-27.
results.creator_credit: Mark Sanders, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: The first episode of this video demonstrates the need for safety precautions at work and at home, and in particular stresses the wearing of protective clothing. In “Building a home” a young couple is offered concise advice on what to do and what not to do when building your own house. The final episode, “Improving health and safety” stresses the necessity of clear, understandable information at the work place on health and safety - including the need for employers, unions and workers to ensure that health and safety information is accessible to all regardless of cultural or linguistic backgrounds.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 22-24.
results.creator_credit: Mandy Smith, Mark Sanders, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode 22, “Finding a place to live” examines the way that government agencies can assist people in selecting public or private accommodation. In “Voting” the Australian electoral system is explained and the importance of informed voting is debated. In “Making a new start” we are given a run-down on the new programs being introduced for unemployed people, particularly New Start and the Job Search Allowance.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 19-21.
results.creator_credit: Mark Sanders, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: Episode 19, “Understanding superannuation” explains in everyday language the different types of superannuation policies available. In “Opening a bank account” the various types of bank and credit accounts are examined and appraised. The final episode on the tape, “Making statistics work for you”, shows how using mathematics in the workplace and at home need not be complicated but rather can make your work less disorganised.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 16-18.
results.creator_credit: Mandy Smith, Ray Quint, Diane Sundin and SBS-TV
results.brief_description: In episode 16 information is given on the workers’ rehabilitation program, as well as helpful advice on activities people can perform at home to alleviate repetitive strain injury. Episode 17 stresses the importance of effective occupational health and safety procedures in the workplace. And in “Solving problems at work”, examples are dramatised on how best to facilitate discussion between employees and employers.
